docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.text:
withForwardInconsistent(forwardInconsistent)

"ForwardInconsistent tells Vault to forward read-after-write requests to the Vault leader instead of simply retrying within a loop. This can increase performance if the option is enabled serverside. https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/configuration/replication#allow_forwarding_via_header"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.vault.withReadYourWrites
docs.text:
withReadYourWrites(readYourWrites)

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn spec.namespaceSelector.withMatchExpressionsMixin
docs.text:
withMatchExpressionsMixin(matchExpressions)

"matchExpressions is a list of label selector requirements. The requirements are ANDed."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.namespaceSelector.withMatchLabels
docs.text:
withMatchLabels(matchLabels)

"matchLabels is a map of {key,value} pairs. A single {key,value} in the matchLabels map is equivalent to an element of matchExpressions, whose key field is \"key\", the operator is \"In\", and the values array contains only \"value\". The requirements are ANDed."

docs.title: fn spec.namespaceSelector.withMatchLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withMatchLabelsMixin(matchLabels)

"matchLabels is a map of {key,value} pairs. A single {key,value} in the matchLabels map is equivalent to an element of matchExpressions, whose key field is \"key\", the operator is \"In\", and the values array contains only \"value\". The requirements are ANDed."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions
docs.text: "matchExpressions is a list of label selector requirements. The requirements are ANDed."

docs.title: fn spec.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withKey
docs.text:
withKey(key)

"key is the label key that the selector applies to."

docs.title: fn spec.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withOperator
docs.text:
withOperator(operator)

"operator represents a key's relationship to a set of values. Valid operators are In, NotIn, Exists and DoesNotExist."

docs.title: fn spec.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withValues
docs.text:
withValues(values)

"values is an array of string values. If the operator is In or NotIn, the values array must be non-empty. If the operator is Exists or DoesNotExist, the values array must be empty. This array is replaced during a strategic merge patch."

docs.title: fn spec.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withValuesMixin
docs.text:
withValuesMixin(values)

"values is an array of string values. If the operator is In or NotIn, the values array must be non-empty. If the operator is Exists or DoesNotExist, the values array must be empty. This array is replaced during a strategic merge patch."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.vault.withForwardInconsistent
docs.text:

"ForwardInconsistent tells Vault to forward read-after-write requests to the Vault leader instead of simply retrying within a loop. This can increase performance if the option is enabled serverside. https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/configuration/replication#allow_forwarding_via_header"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.vault.withReadYourWrites
docs.text:
withReadYourWrites(readYourWrites)

"ReadYourWrites ensures isolated read-after-write semantics by providing discovered cluster replication states in each request. More information about eventual consistency in Vault can be found here https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/enterprise/consistency"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp

withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: obj metadata
docs.text: "ObjectMeta is metadata that all persisted resources must have, which includes all objects users must create."

docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotations
docs.text:
withAnnotations(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotationsMixin
docs.text:
withAnnotationsMixin(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withClusterName
docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

docs.title: fn metadata.withCreationTimestamp
docs.text:
withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabels
docs.text:
withLabels(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

"matchExpressions is a list of label selector requirements. The requirements are ANDed."

docs.text:
withMatchExpressionsMixin(matchExpressions)

"matchExpressions is a list of label selector requirements. The requirements are ANDed."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.conditions.namespaceSelector.withMatchLabels
docs.text:
withMatchLabels(matchLabels)

"matchLabels is a map of {key,value} pairs. A single {key,value} in the matchLabels map is equivalent to an element of matchExpressions, whose key field is \"key\", the operator is \"In\", and the values array contains only \"value\". The requirements are ANDed."

docs.title: fn spec.conditions.namespaceSelector.withMatchLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withMatchLabelsMixin(matchLabels)

"matchLabels is a map of {key,value} pairs. A single {key,value} in the matchLabels map is equivalent to an element of matchExpressions, whose key field is \"key\", the operator is \"In\", and the values array contains only \"value\". The requirements are ANDed."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.conditions.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions
docs.text: "matchExpressions is a list of label selector requirements. The requirements are ANDed."

docs.title: fn spec.conditions.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withKey
docs.text:
withKey(key)

"key is the label key that the selector applies to."

docs.title: fn spec.conditions.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withOperator
docs.text:
withOperator(operator)

"operator represents a key's relationship to a set of values. Valid operators are In, NotIn, Exists and DoesNotExist."

docs.title: fn spec.conditions.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withValues
docs.text:
withValues(values)

"values is an array of string values. If the operator is In or NotIn, the values array must be non-empty. If the operator is Exists or DoesNotExist, the values array must be empty. This array is replaced during a strategic merge patch."

docs.title: fn spec.conditions.namespaceSelector.matchExpressions.withValuesMixin
docs.text:
withValuesMixin(values)

"values is an array of string values. If the operator is In or NotIn, the values array must be non-empty. If the operator is Exists or DoesNotExist, the values array must be empty. This array is replaced during a strategic merge patch."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: generators.v1alpha1.acrAccessToken
docs.text: "ACRAccessToken returns a Azure Container Registry token that can be used for pushing/pulling images. Note: by default it will return an ACR Refresh Token with full access (depending on the identity). This can be scoped down to the repository level using .spec.scope. In case scope is defined it will return an ACR Access Token. \n See docs: https://github.com/Azure/acr/blob/main/docs/AAD-OAuth.md"

docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

docs.title: fn metadata.withCreationTimestamp
docs.text:
withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: obj spec
docs.text: "ACRAccessTokenSpec defines how to generate the access token e.g. how to authenticate and which registry to use. see: https://github.com/Azure/acr/blob/main/docs/AAD-OAuth.md#overview"

docs.title: fn spec.withEnvironmentType
docs.text:
withEnvironmentType(environmentType)

"EnvironmentType specifies the Azure cloud environment endpoints to use for connecting and authenticating with Azure. By default it points to the public cloud AAD endpoint. The following endpoints are available, also see here: https://github.com/Azure/go-autorest/blob/main/autorest/azure/environments.go#L152 PublicCloud, USGovernmentCloud, ChinaCloud, GermanCloud"

docs.title: fn spec.withRegistry
docs.text:
withRegistry(registry)

"the domain name of the ACR registry e.g. foobarexample.azurecr.io"

docs.title: fn spec.withScope
docs.text:
withScope(scope)

"Define the scope for the access token, e.g. pull/push access for a repository. if not provided it will return a refresh token that has full scope. Note: you need to pin it down to the repository level, there is no wildcard available. \n examples: repository:my-repository:pull,push repository:my-repository:pull \n see docs for details: https://docs.docker.com/registry/spec/auth/scope/"

docs.title: fn spec.withTenantId
docs.text:
withTenantId(tenantId)

"TenantID configures the Azure Tenant to send requests to. Required for ServicePrincipal auth type."

docs.title: generators.v1alpha1.ecrAuthorizationToken
docs.text: "ECRAuthorizationTokenSpec uses the GetAuthorizationToken API to retrieve an authorization token. The authorization token is valid for 12 hours. The authorizationToken returned is a base64 encoded string that can be decoded and used in a docker login command to authenticate to a registry. For more information, see Registry authentication (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/Registries.html#registry_auth) in the Amazon Elastic Container Registry User Guide."

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withClusterName
docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

docs.title: fn metadata.withCreationTimestamp
docs.text:
withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabels
docs.text:
withLabels(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

docs.text:

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.withCaBundle
docs.text:
withCaBundle(caBundle)

"PEM encoded CA bundle used to validate Vault server certificate. Only used if the Server URL is using HTTPS protocol. This parameter is ignored for plain HTTP protocol connection. If not set the system root certificates are used to validate the TLS connection."

docs.title: fn spec.provider.withForwardInconsistent
docs.text:
withForwardInconsistent(forwardInconsistent)

"ForwardInconsistent tells Vault to forward read-after-write requests to the Vault leader instead of simply retrying within a loop. This can increase performance if the option is enabled serverside. https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/configuration/replication#allow_forwarding_via_header"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Name of the vault namespace. Namespaces is a set of features within Vault Enterprise that allows Vault environments to support Secure Multi-tenancy. e.g: \"ns1\". More about namespaces can be found here https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/enterprise/namespaces"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.withPath
docs.text:
withPath(path)

"Path is the mount path of the Vault KV backend endpoint, e.g: \"secret\". The v2 KV secret engine version specific \"/data\" path suffix for fetching secrets from Vault is optional and will be appended if not present in specified path."

docs.title: fn spec.provider.withReadYourWrites
docs.text:
withReadYourWrites(readYourWrites)

"ReadYourWrites ensures isolated read-after-write semantics by providing discovered cluster replication states in each request. More information about eventual consistency in Vault can be found here https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/enterprise/consistency"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.withServer
docs.text:
withServer(server)

"Server is the connection address for the Vault server, e.g: \"https://vault.example.com:8200\"."

docs.title: fn spec.provider.withVersion
docs.text:
withVersion(version)

"Version is the Vault KV secret engine version. This can be either \"v1\" or \"v2\". Version defaults to \"v2\"."

docs.title: obj spec.provider.auth.kubernetes.serviceAccountRef
docs.text: "Optional service account field containing the name of a kubernetes ServiceAccount. If the service account is specified, the service account secret token JWT will be used for authenticating with Vault. If the service account selector is not supplied, the secretRef will be used instead."

docs.title: fn metadata.withClusterName
docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.vault.withForwardInconsistent
docs.text:
withForwardInconsistent(forwardInconsistent)

"ForwardInconsistent tells Vault to forward read-after-write requests to the Vault leader instead of simply retrying within a loop. This can increase performance if the option is enabled serverside. https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/configuration/replication#allow_forwarding_via_header"

docs.title: fn spec.provider.vault.withReadYourWrites
docs.text:
withReadYourWrites(readYourWrites)

"ReadYourWrites ensures isolated read-after-write semantics by providing discovered cluster replication states in each request. More information about eventual consistency in Vault can be found here https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/enterprise/consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"
